metadata.case_name: Bansilal Abirchand Kasturchand v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appellant is sole proprietor of firm Bansilal Abirchand Kasturchand, carrying on business as money-lenders, dealers in shares and bullion and commission agents in Bombay, Calcutta and other places. He is resident of Bikaner and manages business through agents.
Agent at Bombay was Chandratan, holding power-of-attorney dated May 13, 1944, conferring large powers of management including authority to operate on bank accounts.

During November 15, 1944 to November 23, 1944, agent withdrew from firm's bank account sums aggregating to Rs. 2,30,636-4-0 and applied them in satisfaction of his personal debts in speculative transactions.
On November 25, 1944, cashier of firm sent telegram to appellant informing him of the true state of affairs.
Appellant went to Bombay on December 3, 1944, and on December 4, 1944, cancelled the power-of-attorney given to the agent.
By notice dated December 6, 1944, appellant called upon agent to pay the amounts withdrawn.
Agent replied on December 8, 1944, admitting misappropriation and pleading for mercy.
On January 16, 1945, appellant filed suit against agent in High Court of Bombay for recovery of Rs. 2,30,636-4-0, decreed on February 20, 1945.
Rs. 28,000 recovered from Chandratan and adjusted towards decree; balance of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 written off at end of accounting year as irrecoverable.
Tribunal found amount represented loss by misappropriation by agent Chandratan but held not trading loss per Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield Ltd.
Tribunal referred question to High Court Nagpur under s.66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
High Court Nagpur answered question against appellant per Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield Ltd.; application under s.66A dismissed.
Appellant obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 136.

legal_issues.text: Whether the said sum of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 being part of the amount embezzled by the assessee's Munim is allowable as a deduction under the Indian Income-tax Act either under Section 10(1) or under the general principles of determining the profit and loss of the assessee or Section 10(2)(xv)?

petitioner_arguments.text: Loss sustained by reason of embezzlement is a bad debt allowable under s.10(2)(xi) of the Act.
It is a business expense falling within s.10(2)(xv) of the Act.
It is a trading loss which must be taken into account in computing the profits under s.10(1) of the Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10(1) Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; ordinary commercial principles

respondent_arguments.text: Amount not admissible deduction as not trading loss per Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield Ltd.
No evidence that withdrawal by Chandratan was for purpose of making advance; power-of-attorney related to private affairs too.

court_reasoning.text: Deduction not admissible under s.10(2)(xi) as debt does not arise out of contract; merely journal entries do not import contractual liability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Misappropriation in fraud and breach of obligations not contractual debt.

court_reasoning.text: Not admissible under s.10(2)(xv) as withdrawals without authority and in fraud not expenditure for business purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for business.

court_reasoning.text: Loss from embezzlement by employee is trading loss under s.10(1) if arises out of carrying on business and incidental to it; business carried through agents, losses incidental to such employment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: According to ordinary commercial principles, such losses must be deducted to arrive at true profits.

court_reasoning.text: Curtis v. J.G. Oldfield distinguished: there embezzlement de hors trade; here in banking/money-lending, operations on bank account continuous and incidental.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Withdrawal in purported exercise of authority referable to character as agent.

court_reasoning.text: Agrees with Venkatachalapathy Iyer, Lords Dairy Farm, Motipur Sugar Factory: loss incidental to business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to prove withdrawal for specific advance; authority to operate bank makes it business-related.

holdings.text: Loss sustained by appellant as result of misappropriation by Chandratan is incidental to carrying on of business and deductible in computing profits under s.10(1) of the Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Embezzlement by managing director de hors trade; not applicable to agent in money-lending business.
Bad debts deductible under s.10(1) even without specific provision; account must take all losses for true profits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles
precedents_cited.relevance: Profits understood in natural commercial sense.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co. v. Income-tax Commissioner
Jagarnath Therani v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Embezzlement by gumastha incidental to business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramaswami Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Theft by strangers not incidental; distinguishes employee embezzlement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bansidhar Onkarmal v. Commissioner of Income-tax
Venkatachalapathy Iyer v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Accountant short-totalling and misappropriating incidental to business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lords Dairy Farm Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Defalcation by employee is trading loss.

precedents_cited.case_name: Motipur Sugar Factory Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Loss by robbery of employee entrusted with funds incidental.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: s.10(1) allows trading losses incidental to business; not under (2)(xi) or (2)(xv); reference under s.66(1)

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of High Court set aside; question referred answered in affirmative that loss is deductible under s.10(1).
outcome.relief_granted: Loss of Rs. 2,02,442-13-9 allowed as deduction.

key_quotes.text: "What are chargeable in income-tax in respect of a business are the profits and gains of a year and in assessing the amount of the profits and gains of a year account must necessarily be taken of all losses incurred, otherwise you would not arrive at the true profits and gains."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes necessity of deducting losses for true profits under s.10(1).

key_quotes.text: "The word profits is to be understood... in its natural and proper sense-in a sense which no commercial man would misunderstand."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms commercial principles govern computation of profits.

key_quotes.text: "If employment of agents is incidental to the carrying on of business, it must logically follow that losses which are incidental to such employment are also incidental to the carrying on of the business."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for allowing embezzlement loss as trading loss.
